displayed_text: Family Member: everyone gets chemo. Which is great for me, you’re like wow, I guess it’s great for you but you know we all have mixed feelings a little bit. I get that. Patient: Right. Doctor: The second study is chemotherapy plus an immunotherapy versus chemotherapy. So, docetaxel plus immunotherapy versus docetaxel. So, you know, either one of those is doable. Again, if you had stuff outside of bone that’s probably what we should do. Hi, oh, for the opioids, Okay, for your pain, yeah. So, then the other part is what if you’re just bone. So, let’s say we do this and you’re just in your bones, no lymph nodes, liver, nothing, it’s clean then I think we should consider radium or Xofigo. Family Member: Together with the docetaxel? Doctor: No, just radium. So, there it’s um to combine with anything else is not standard of care and we don’t have our trial up yet with radium plus something. But, at this moment standard of care is just monthly radium for six months and that improves your survival span. So does chemotherapy but radium you can only give if it’s just in bone. So, if you have it like in the liver or whatever kind of like when we first started Patient: Um hum. Doctor: it was like oh, no you kind of had these bits and pieces, Patient: Right. Doctor: one, your insurance won’t approve it and number two it’s the wrong treatment. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But, if that’s sort of gone and nowhere to be found on this CAT scan then I think radium is it. Now, radium does two things. One is that it helps you live longer but also helps with pain so those people who are, you know, whether you’re taking a Tylenol over-the-counter or you’re taking actual narcotics that should improve. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: We sort of made that be like uh a line in the sand so to speak, so- Patient: What about the PSMA, uh? Doctor: So that was going to be the next thing. Patient: Oh. Okay. Doctor: Uh, we, there’s going to be a trial that’s a multi-centered trial that coming on-line, but it’s going to be a while. Uh, right now I think the trial is still ongoing at Cornell. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And there’s actually a group that would get you back to California. There’s a group at UCLA (laughs) Patient: And how does, what’s the effect of that when you get treated? I mean what is, what’s different about that? Would that, would that go after the growth in the lymph nodes? Doctor: Yes. So PSMA is a thing that’s on the surface of crossing cancer cells. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And it’s an enzyme, which means uh we’re not really sure what it does but we are, we’re able to block its function with a with a small drug. Uh and what people actually here when we started doing it, uh people thought well that would be cool to take an image of the cancer-

Family Member: Next Friday we’ll be back to plan out the next step and… Doctor: That’s what I’m thinking. Family Member: The tests should be back by then? Doctor: Yeah, but you know what just for now wait for a phone call and I’ll have S call you as soon as we get the results so we can sort of plan better for that Friday. Family Member: So it’s just a one day in and out thing? Doctor: Yeah, yeah. Show me how is the shoulder doing? Patient: Oh the shoulders are good. Doctor: Okay what is…? Patient: I don’t have any you know… Doctor: Is this ten mg? Patient: Five in the morning, five at night. Doctor: Okay did it flare up after the treatment last time? Family Member: No.

Family Member: Why don’t we just stop it. Doctor: So go ahead and stop it for now. And we’ll restart it once we feel comfortable that there’s no bleeding and you know… Patient: Okay so I’m off the aspirin. Even the little ones? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Totally off the aspirin. Healthcare Professional: Even the baby aspirin. Family Member: And that’s what B____ said. Patient: I know. Okay. Family Member: Um. Healthcare Professional: Let me get your reports copied. Family Member: Do you mind if we, is it possible to sit in here and read through the consent? Just so we have… Doctor: That’s fine. It’s just that do you want to - are you okay with doing that? Patient: No, no, let’s take our time.

Family Member: I think it’s a echocardiogram… Healthcare Professional: Phase I. Patient: Can I bring a book? Doctor: Oh yeah, yeah. They even have movies and they have a TV there. Family Member: You’re gonna bring me too. I’m definitely coming to this. Doctor: They have all kinds of stuff to do there. Patient: Do they have people that know how to put in an IV? Doctor: Yes they do. Well yeah. Family Member: So you think it would be one IV and then all the drugs through the IV? Doctor: Right. Yeah. Family Member: That’s much better. Doctor: That way you don’t get poked five times. If you have five blood draws.

Patient: Yeah, yeah. (chuckles) Doctor: This is such a generous gift. Today today I am wearing my uh socks. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: You know Patient: Oh they talking about sending some in December, you heard. Just some socks. Doctor: I did. Patient: Yeah, mhm. Doctor: But next time you come in I going to have to wear these. Doctor: The polka dot socks. Patient: Yeah. (laughs) Doctor: Perfect. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: It goes there for now. How have you been?

Patient: It passes freely. (Pause) Doctor: Anything else you want to tell me about how you feel? Patient: I think I do. Family Member: Okay. Patient: I did take iron. I just had my, my hip redone. I had it replaced seven years ago, but it got loose. And they took it apart and put some – Doctor: When was that? Patient: February Doctor: But not since you last saw me? Patient: Oh, no. But I did take iron then, but I haven’t taken it since. So. Doctor: Have you been thinking clearly? Any issues with your – just how you process things? Patient: No. (Clicking) Doctor: Anything new on your body today? Rashes? Skin changes?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: And that’s what we’re following. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Right now, there is no evidence that it has gone any place else in your body. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But we’ll continue to follow that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright? Patient: That’s good. That’s good. I’m going to keep the faith that everything is, is good. Doctor: Okay. Now very good. (pause7sec) Patient: I try not to worry. You know? Doctor: Yeah. Don’t worry.

Patient: I didn’t ever know. I didn’t realize, I didn’t realize this is my third year doing it, and I didn’t realize I was - Doctor: No shave, but I, I think that’s what that fundraiser is for. Patient: This is just County Sherriff’s Department. Doctor: No shave November. So, Movember, it is a big - they raise millions. Patient: No kidding. Doctor: They give, uh, grants and do a lot of support for, uh- Yeah, this is my eighth year. (softly) Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um. No new allergies? Patient: No. Doctor: I’m going through your medicines. Still taking your Advair as needed? Patient: Right. Doctor: Your atorvastatin ten milligrams a day? Patient: Yes.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Alright I was wondering if uh… Patient: How about the CAT scan? Doctor: CAT scan I just called them. Patient: Sure. Doctor: They’re still loading the images. So they said they’ll let me know in a few minutes once it’s ready. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay let me try and I’m going to… Patient: Take a look. Doctor: Did they put it in yet? Family Member: No. Doctor: Let me at least have it uploaded. Patient: Yeah.
